articles.title: About Me
articles.contents:
Halina Do-Linh achieved a Bachelor’s Degree in Environmental
Studies & Biology from the University of California, Santa Cruz
(UCSC). There she grew her interests in sustainable
development, field research and conservation.


Her interest in an environmental career was solidified after
researching green and hawksbill sea turtles in Baja California through
the Ecology and Conservation Supercourse field quarter
at UC Santa Cruz.


After graduating, Halina applied her field research
skills to outdoor education, where she taught
environmental topics to K-12 students and later, field
research methods to University of California
undergraduates.


In 2018, she moved to Los Angeles to work for Heal the Bay,
an environmental non-profit focused on safe, clean water. There
she garnered support for environmental campaigns including the
Safe, Clean Water Program (Measure W) and The
California Circular Economy and Plastic Pollution Reduction Act
(SB 54 and AB 1080). These campaigns expanded Halina’s
knowledge of watershed health, environmental justice, and
environmental policy. Though these campaigns were successful,
she recognized there were data inaccuracies in representation and in
metrics.



To gain the skills to overcome these data challenges, Halina is
studying Environmental
Data Science at the Bren School of Environmental Science &
Management. After Bren, Halina plans to apply her training
in data science to finding equitable solutions for environmental issues
affecting urban watersheds.

articles.title: Halina Do-Linh
articles.contents:
Halina Do-Linh
          
          
          Home
          About
          Blog
          Resume
          
          
          
          ☰
          
          
      
        
          
            
          
            Halina Do-Linh
          
          
            
          
          
            Hello! I am an environmental data scientist with a
            multidisciplinary background who cares about urban
            environmental systems and the people within them. Usually
            you can find me in the mountains, but this summer I’m closer
            to the ocean building an interactive R Shiny dashboard for
            the Bren School of Environmental Science &
            Management.
            This June, I graduated from UCSB’s Master of Environmental
            Data Science program. For my
            capstone, I built a Shiny app to support federal public
            land managers efforts to ensure equitable access to
            campgrounds on federal public lands in California. It’s
            called the Outdoor
            Equity App and is live - check it out to explore
            relationships between campsite reservations and
            socioeconomic demographic data.
            Click around and I look forward to connecting with
            you.
